thread.title: Conway makes up 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend Trump's ban
thread.title_full: Conway makes up 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend Trump's ban

author: CHRIS SOMMERFELDT
title: Conway makes up 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend Trump's ban

organizations.name: u.s. attorney's office western district of kentucky
office western district of kentucky/daily news

text:
Kellyanne Conway makes up 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend President Trump's immigration ban Conway makes up 'Bowling Green massacre' to defend Trump's ban Thursday, February 2, 2017, 11:48 PM 
Perhaps it was an alternative massacre? 
Kellyanne Conway, a senior counselor to President Trump, appeared to concoct a fake "massacre" while justifying Trump's controversial executive order on immigration during a Thursday night interview. 
"I bet it's brand new information to people that President Obama had a six-month ban on the Iraqi refugee program after two Iraqis came here to this country, were radicalized and they were the masterminds behind the Bowling Green massacre," Conway told MSNBC's Chris Matthews . "Most people don't know that because it didn't get covered." 
Social media users were quick to point out that the supposed "massacre" didn't get any media coverage because it never actually happened. Kellyanne Conway (alongside White House adviser Steve Bannon) evoked a massacre that appears to have never happened in a Thursday night interview. (JOSHUA ROBERTS/REUTERS) 
"This is the message (Conway) is sending to Iraqis: I hate you & make stuff up, now please help our deployed US personnel in Iraq," Democratic California Rep. Ted Lieu tweeted after viewing the segment . 
The White House did not immediately return a request for clarification, but it's possible Conway was referring to Mohanad Shareef Hammadi, 25, and Waad Ramadan Alwan, 41 - two Iraqi nationals who were sentenced to long prison sentences for taking part in attacks against U.S. troops in their homecountry in 2011, according to the Justice Department. 
The two men lived in Bowling Green, Kentucky at the time of their indictment, but there is no information about either of them carrying out a "massacre" - or any violent offenses, for that matter - on U.S. soil. This undated photo provided by U.S. Attorney's Office Western District of Kentucky shows Waad Ramadan Alwan. From a Kentucky college town, Alwan and Mohanad Shareef Hammadi, Iraqi refugees plotted to send sniper rifles, Stinger missiles and money to al-Qaida operatives waging an insurgency back home against U.S. troops. The scheme was foiled and both are in prison, but the case has left jitters about whether terrorists might slip in among Syrian refugees resettling in the U.S. (U.S. Attorney's Office Western District of Kentucky/Daily News via AP) (U.S. Attorney's Office/AP) This undated photo provided by U.S. Attorney's Office Western District of Kentucky shows Mohanad Shareef Hammadi. From a Kentucky college town, Hammadi and Waad Ramadan Alwan, Iraqi refugees, plotted to send sniper rifles, Stinger missiles and money to al-Qaida operatives waging an insurgency back home against U.S. troops. The scheme was foiled and both are in prison, but the case has left jitters about whether terrorists might slip in among Syrian refugees resettling in the U.S. (U.S. Attorney's Office Western District of Kentucky/Daily News via AP) (U.S. Attorney's Office/AP) 
Conway might have been referring to Waad Ramadan Alwan and Mohanad Shareef Hammadi, who never carried out an attack on U.S. soil. 
Conway's remark about Obama's "six-month ban" might have referred to the 2011 review of vetting procedures for Iraqi nationals that the former President ordered in light of the indictment of Hammadi and Alwan. The review was, however, not in any sense a ban. 
Sean Spicer compares 'alternative facts' to weather forecasts 
Conway's conspicuous "massacre" comment comes less than two weeks after she defended false assertions about the size of Trump's inauguration crowd as "alternative facts." 
"You're saying it's a falsehood. And they're giving — Sean Spicer, our press secretary — gave alternative facts," Conway told NBC's Chuck Todd about Spicer's claim that the Jan. 20 crowd was "the largest audience to ever witness an inauguration, period." "Most people don't know that because it didn't get covered," Conway said of the apparently fake massacre. (Evan Vucci/AP) 
Todd scoffed in response, "Alternative facts aren't facts, they are falsehoods." 
The exchange went viral immediately and prompted the "Alternative Facts" hashtag to trend across multiple social media platforms. Join the Conversation:
